description: From Middle English clod, a late by-form of clot, from Old English clot, from Proto-West Germanic *klott (“mass, ball, clump”). Compare clot and cloud; cognate to Dutch klodde (“rag”) and kloot (“clod”).

entries.meaning: A lump of something, especially of earth or clay.
The ground; the earth; a spot of earth or turf.
examples: the clod where once their sultan's horse hath trod
'What was its number?''I don't know, sir.''You clod! Why didn't you call one of our men, whoever was nearest, and leave him to shadow the American while you followed the cab?'

entries.meaning: Part of a shoulder of beef, or of the neck piece near the shoulder.

verbs.description: clod (third-person singular simple present clods, present participle clodding, simple past and past participle clodded)

examples: "When I went there yesterday evening in the gloaming it had crept down and was trying to catch the little speckled fishes that play in the pool, and I had to clod it to make it go up the tree again and let them alone."

entries.meaning: (transitive, Scotland) To throw violently; to hurl.
To collect into clods, or into a thick mass; to coagulate; to clot.
